trial_identification.studytitle: Prospective clinical study using X-ray to evaluate fixation of cementless total knee replacement components
trial_identification.scientifictitle: In patients with osteoarthritis of the knee, do cementless total knee replacement components, comparing radiographic micromotion at 6 months and 2 years, provide adequate long-term fixation at the implant-bone interface.

interventions.interventions: Total knee arthroplasty will be performed using a traditional medial parapatellar approach. Distal femur and proximal tibia resections will be completed using intramedullary alignments jigs. Implantation of the femoral and tibial tray components will be performed without the use of bone cement. The approximate duration of the procedure is 90-120 minutes. Micromotion of the implanted components will be assessed by X-ray, using the pre-weight-bearing position as the base for subsequent measurements.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Radiographic micromotion, consisting of component migration and rotation relative to the proximal tibia and distal femur.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Post-op before weight-bearing; 6 weeks post-op; 3 months post-op; 6 months post-op; 1 year post-op; 2 years post-op

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Knee function assessed before and after surgery using International Knee Society Score (IKSS), SF-36, Western Ontario and McMaster Universities Questionnaire(WOMAC), Oxford Knee Score, Self-Administrered Comorbidity Questionnaire, Patient Catastrophising Scale, University of California Los Angeles (UCLA) Activity Level Scale.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Pre-op, 6 weeks post-op; 3 months post-op; 6 months post-op; 1 year post-op; 2 years post-op

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Knee function using Walkabout Portable Gait Monitor.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: 1. Symptomatic osteoarthritis of the knee requiring intervention. 2. Between the ages of 21 and 80 years inclusive. 3. Ability to give informed consent.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: 1. Significant co-morbidity affecting ability to ambulate 2. Flexion contracture greater than 15 degrees 3. Extension lag greater than 10 degrees 4. Tibial subluxation greater than 10mm on standing radiograph 5. Prior arthroplasty, patellectomy or osteotomy with the affected knee 6. Lateral or medial collateral ligament instability (>10 degrees varus/valgus) 7. Leg length discrepancy greater than 10mm 8. Active or prior infection 9. Morbid obesity (Body Mass Index, BMI > 40) 10. Medical condition precluding major surgery 11. Severe osteoporosis or osteopenia 12 Neuromuscular impairment

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This study assesses the clinical performance of implants used to treat osteoarthritis using total knee replacement. Highly-accurate X-rays will be used to measure any small motions of the implant components at regular intervals after the knee replacement operation. The health status of patients and ability for them to perform activities of daily living will also be measured. This information will be used to confirm that new methods of securing the knee replacement components to the bone are clinically effective.
